name: Ruins at Westerplatte
description: The site of the first battle of World War II.

name: Wisłoujście Fortress
description: This 700-year-old structure is one of the most unique architectural and historic monuments in Gdańsk.

name: Upside-Down House
description: Communism's topsy-turvy effect on Poland has been brought to life in this wacky tourist trap.

name: Gdansk Astronomical Clock
description: A huge wooden clock that is so beautiful its creator was forcibly blinded.

name: Łapalice Castle
description: This imposing 20th-century castle was abandoned before it was ever completed.

name: Hotel Zdrowie
description: A haunting deserted hotel is a favorite with artists and photographers.

name: Malbork Castle
description: This 13th century Gothic brick castle is the largest in the world by surface area.

name: Krzywy Domek - Crooked House
description: This fairytale inspired, warped building houses restaurants, shops, and a radio station.

name: Torpedownia
description: A World War II torpedo launch station abandoned off the Polish coast.

name: Gdańsk Shipyard
description: A floundering Polish shipyard was once the soul of the Solidarity movement that capsized communism.

name: Old Prussian Hags of Northern Pomerania
description: These rare statues are one of the few remaining material witnesses to Old Prussian culture.
itemLabel: Old Prussian Hags of Northern Pomerania

name: The Three Boar Heads of Gdańsk
description: A mysterious emblem tucked in an small alleyway is actually the coat of arms of a heroic medieval family.
itemLabel: The Three Boar Heads of Gdańsk

name: Cemetery of Lost Cemeteries
description: Memorial to the lost dead of Gdansk, whose resting places were destroyed during World War II.

name: Dwór Artusa
description: A merchant court dedicated to the fictitious King Arthur is heavily adorned with bizarre Renaissance art.

name: Fahrenheit Monument
description: This antique thermometer honors the creator of the first universal temperature scale.

name: Falowiec
description: This Communist-era residential block is one of the longest residential building in Europe.

name: Monument to the Defenders of the Polish Post Office
description: Modern art commemorates one of the first military actions of World War II.
itemLabel: Monument to the Defenders of the Polish Post Office

name: Carthusian Church Monastery
description: The coffin-shaped church was once home to monks who slept in coffins.

name: Tower Clock Museum
description: This museum in the tower of the oldest church in Gdańsk, is home to centuries-old time-keeping devices and the world's first pulsar clock.

name: St. Bridget's Church
description: One of the world's largest amber altarpieces is housed within this reconstructed medieval church.

name: Archaeological Remains at Hala Targowa (Market Hall)
description: Several 12th-century ruins can be found inside this historical market.
itemLabel: Archaeological Remains at Hala Targowa (Market Hall)

name: Lunar Rover at Mariacka Street
description: During the renovation of this bas-relief, the constructors added one unusual element.

name: Beached Wreck of the Warship Grom II
description: The rusting hulk of a Soviet warship sits on a Polish beach.
itemLabel: Beached Wreck of the Warship Grom II

name: Gdański Lew Hewelion
description: Gdańsk's lion mascot features in a trail of bronze sculptures scattered all across the city.
